framework_intro.para: Here is a framework to help you write an argument essay. There are spaces for you to add the content of your essay.

commentary.para: The argument essay is one of the most common types of essay you will encounter at school or university. In this type of essay, you need to display your ability to weigh up different viewpoints and arrive at an informed conclusion. These viewpoints are a result of reading and evaluating research on the topic.
In most cases, the essay will require you to state what your opinion is, but in some cases it might only be a presentation of a series of arguments and counterarguments.

The model text is an extract from an essay about language acquisition by deaf children. It is divided into four parts—introduction, spoken language acquisition, sign language acquisition and conclusion.
The introduction features three key things:
background information on the topic
a specific introduction to the topic
the scope and aim of the essay
The writer discusses arguments against their case (that sign language is a more natural choice of communication).

This section explores research around the first topic (the issue of how deaf children acquire spoken language) and lists the different methods available (speech reading, cued speech and other factors).

The purpose of this section is to point out the difficulties deaf children have with acquiring spoken language and how the different methods of getting them to acquire spoken language are unsuccessful.
All the points are supported by research studies.
The writer discusses arguments for their case (that sign language is a more natural choice of communication).
This section promotes the second topic (the use of sign language) as the solution to the problem deaf children face with communication, highlighted in the previous section.
It begins by presenting an alternative combined system, where the parents also learn sign language, and ends by suggesting that sign language is the most useful solution.
All the points are supported by research studies.
The conclusion first summarizes and evaluates the approaches discussed in the essay.
Then it presents opposing views to the argument (the use of sign language) promoted in the previous section.

It ends by addressing the opposing views through promoting a different approach, the informed conclusion, (a bilingual approach, using sign language and learning oral skills, as the most effective means of teaching deaf children how to communicate.)
Phrases which express the writer's viewpoints more objectively.
Words which show the connection and progression of the argument.
Hedging language is useful for putting your view across less assertively.
Appropriate reporting verbs show how the cited source fits in with your argument.

checklist.point: Read widely around your topic. Make notes of the different points that emerge in your reading.
Focus on the question and decide what your stance is going to be.

Select two or three arguments and identify suitable supporting evidence. Explain each argument in terms of how it supports your viewpoint or provides an opposing argument, which you then argue against (i.e. present evidence which questions the validity of the opposing argument).
Use counterarguments.
Provide good evidence.
Decide on a suitable organization of your ideas.
Make some notes and organize them into the plan.
Use academic language.
Language Bank: showing your position
Language Bank: hedging
Language Bank: showing progression in your argument
Think about the writing process.
Have I got a good understanding of the topic and decided on my position?
Have I chosen an appropriate structure?
Have I given a clear introduction to the essay?
Have I presented both arguments and counterarguments clearly?
Have I provided suitable supporting evidence for the arguments and counterarguments?
Have I arrived at an informed conclusion?
Have I used linking words and phrases to show the development of my argument?
Have I used appropriate language to reflect my position?
Have I used hedging language?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?

paragraph.name: Writing Essays 2: an argument essay
paragraph.desc: In an argument essay, you need to display your ability to weigh up different viewpoints and arrive at an informed conclusion.

paragraph.name: Introduction
paragraph.desc:
Begin with background information on the topic.

Give a specific explanation of the topic.

State the aims and/or scope of the essay.

content.para:
Introduction
There are approximately 688 000 people who are severely or profoundly deaf in the United Kingdom, and 840 children who are born deaf each year (RNID, 2011a). It is clear from these figures that there is a large community of people who are deaf in the United Kingdom alone. Consequently, it must be considered how deafness may affect language acquisition and what steps caregivers can take to overcome any difficulties. There are different levels of deafness and hearing loss (RNID, 2011b); however, it is not within the scope of this essay to consider all of these levels. Therefore, this essay will mainly focus on people who are born with severe or profound deafness (RNID, 2011b).

paragraph.name: Arguments against your case
paragraph.desc: Present the arguments against your case, including supporting evidence.
paragraph.tip: TIP Evidence is crucial for any argument. You can draw on statistics, the results of research studies, newspaper reports/editorials or case studies.

paragraph.name: Conclusion
paragraph.desc: Summarize your points and explain your informed conclusion.

content.para:
Conclusion
In conclusion, this essay has … [Evaluation of the approaches suggested in the essay follows.] … Thus, it seems that sign language is a more natural choice of communication. This has implications … [Elaboration on the implications follows.] … Although some parents may be concerned that learning a sign language will isolate their child from the community of hearing people, Mayberry et al.
